I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Socialist  Republic  of  Viet  Nam  for  the  Trade  Facilitation:  Improved  Sanitary  and 
Phytosanitary Handling in Greater Mekong Subregion Trade Project.1 
 
2. 
The project will strengthen institutions and operational and management capacity in Viet 
Nam for operating a cost-effective sanitary and phytosanitary (SPS) system that facilitates trade 
and  protects  health.2  It  responds  to  major  concerns  in  the  Greater  Mekong  Subregion  (GMS) 
over  SPS  handling  and  food  safety,  especially  (i)  weak  harmonization  and  coordination  with 
regional  and  international  SPS  and  food  safety  requirements,  (ii)  insufficient  institutional 
contacts  between  GMS  countries  and  lack  of  trust  in  each  other's  systems,  and  (iii)  major 
capacity  gaps.  The  project  will  focus  on  GMS  trade  in  food  products  to  which  SPS  measures 
apply.  It  will  establish,  strengthen,  and  implement  (i)  surveillance  and  inspection  programs  for 
food  safety,  including  safer  food  handling  in  the  tourism  industry;  and  (ii)  regional  cooperation 
and harmonization of SPS management in food trade. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

trade,  GMS  governments 

increasingly  acknowledge  that  weak 

 
A. 
 
The  GMS  regional  cooperation  strategy  and  program  focuses  on  connectivity  and 
3. 
competitiveness.  While  recent  investments  in  physical  infrastructure  have  created  new 
opportunities  for 
legal, 
institutional,  and  administrative  capacity  hinders  the  optimal  use  of  infrastructure  and  makes  it 
difficult  to  minimize  trade-related  health  hazards.  Some  initiatives  have  been  launched  to 
overcome these constraints, such as the GMS cross-border transport agreement. The midterm 
review  of  the  GMS  strategic  framework  (2002–2012)  reaffirmed  the  importance  of  trade  and 
transport  facilitation  initiatives,  including  strengthening  of  SPS  capacity  and  cooperation.  The 
GMS action plan for SPS system arrangements, 2010–2015 identified the essential SPS issues 
that need to be resolved to meet the development needs of the GMS. The project fits within the 
GMS  regional  cooperation  strategy  and  program  and  is  included  in  the  Viet  Nam  country 
operations business plan.3 
 
4.  
Trade  in  the  GMS  is  growing  rapidly,  especially  in  SPS-affected  products,  particularly 
food  and  food  products.  As  incomes  rose  across  most  GMS  countries,  total  recorded  GMS 
exports  of  agriculture,  food,  and  forestry  (AFF)  products  (for  which  SPS  measures  apply) 
reached  $9.27 billion  in  2009.  This  represents  an  average  annual  growth  of  more  than  10% 
since  2000.  Viet  Nam,  in  2009,  exported  about  $2  billion  of  AFF  products  to  the  other  GMS 
countries, of which 53% were food products. It imported $1.3 billion of AFF products, of which 
73% was food. Tourist arrivals in Viet Nam are also on the rise and reached more than 5 million 
in 2010, an increase of 30% over 2009. The tourism sector is an important exporter of services.

Notwithstanding these positive developments, the weak SPS system seriously hampers 
5. 
further  growth  of  food  trade  and  improvement  in  food  safety,  which  affects  not  only  the 
investment climate, both regionally and nationally, but also the profitability of the private sector. 
Food exports remain largely bulk commodities. Agriculture input management is poor, and food-
processing  standards  are  low.  Weak  food  safety  control  measures  in  imports  and  domestic 
markets  lead  to  food-related  disease  outbreaks  and  high  risks  for  investors.  Poor  public 
response  capacity  can  result  in  blanket  bans  and/or  imposition  of  complex  technical  product 
requirements  by  importing  countries.  Moreover,  SPS  and  food  safety  management  capacity 
affects  human  well-being  and  incomes.  Currently,  food  safety  requirements  in  most  countries 
are tightening, driven by greater consumer awareness, urbanization and modern lifestyles, food 
quality  scares,  and  inadequate  response  of  regulators  and  food  companies  to  food  safety 
incidents. The international trend in food control systems is that private sector entities assume 
the responsibility to produce and market safe food, but governments issue technical guidelines, 
provide  regulatory  oversight,  and  ensure  adequate  enforcement.  To  do  this,  public  systems 
need  institutional  capacity  for  process  control  and  conformity  testing,  supported  by  adequate 
laboratory facilities. Where such arrangements exist, public inspection rates can be low.4 
 
6. 
Given  the  diversity  of  its  agricultural  products  and  the  wide  range  of  trade  issues,  Viet 
Nam  faces  greater  and  more  complex  food  safety  surveillance  tasks  than  the  smaller  GMS 
countries. The SPS–food safety situation in Viet Nam is characterized by: 

(i) 

 (ii) 

(iii) 

Lack  of  systematic  national  planning  and  implementation  of  active  and  passive 
surveillance,5  which  affects  the  robustness  and  reliability  of  the  food  safety 
system.  In  laboratories,  diagnostic  and  testing  systems  are  insufficiently 
harmonized  and  do  not  always  meet  international  standards.  Participation  in 
proficiency  testing  is  limited.  The  existing  capacity  is  underutilized  because  of 
inadequate operational funds.6 
Lack  of  sound  food  safety  management  capacity  for  exports  to  domestic  and 
regional  (GMS)  markets. While  efforts  to  meet  international  SPS  standards  can 
be  very  good  for  some  exports,  such  as  fish  and  fish  products  for  the 
Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development markets, performance 
in other areas—e.g., food products that are geared toward the domestic market 
and trade with GMS countries—is often poor.7 Capacity for risk-based handling of 
food  imports,  and  for  active  and  passive  surveillance  is  weak,  particularly 
provincial capacity. 
Limited capacity of the Viet Nam Food Administration (VFA), established in 1999 
under the Ministry of Health (MOH), for managing food safety tasks mandated by 
the Food Safety Law of July 2010. There is no central planning and compilation 
and analysis of data. 

 
7.  
Policy  and  sector  relevance.  The  Government  of  Viet  Nam  recognizes  the  need  to 
modernize  AFF  production  and  boost  international  trade  competitiveness.  The  Socioeconomic 
Development  Plan,  2011–2015  anticipates  a  restructuring  of  economic  activity  toward  greater 
technological  content  of  Vietnamese  goods  and  a  deepening  of  international  economic

integration, including application of standards and SPS practices. The project is aligned with the 
targets  of  the  Socio-economic  Development  Plan, 
the  Five-Year  Plan  for  Agriculture 
Development, 2011–2015, the National SPS Action Plan, and the National Action Plan for Food 
Safety, as well as the Law on Food Safety (2010). The project is also in line with the GMS 10-
year strategic framework, 2012–2022, and supports the drive to facilitate cross-border trade and 
investment.  The  project  will  contribute  to  pillar  4  (cooperation  in  regional  public  goods)  of  the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy of the Asian Development Bank (ADB),8 and is 
consistent with the GMS core agriculture support program. 
 
8. 
Lessons from trade facilitation and sanitary and phytosanitary development. Trade 
facilitation  remains  a  challenging  agenda  in  the  GMS,  and  covers  many  aspects.  Previous 
experience  shows  the  need  to  adopt  a  phased  approach  by  formulating  well-targeted  and 
sequenced projects that lift the capacity of the weak link and ensure implementation of bilateral 
and  regional  commitments—GMS  and  Association  of  Southeast  Asian  Nations  (ASEAN)—on 
cooperation and harmonization. In addition, support for SPS food safety needs to be delivered 
over  an  extended  period  to  allow  enough  time  to  develop  national  risk-based  surveillance 
systems  gradually  and  systematically.  Inadequate  country-specific  capacity  is  a  major 
impediment 
regional  cooperation  and  harmonization  of  SPS  measures. 
Development  partners  support  various  aspects  of  food  safety  management  in  Viet  Nam,  but 
ongoing projects have not focused on building food safety capacity in a comprehensive manner. 
Preparatory  work  has  been  firmly  anchored  in  the  lessons  from  international  experience  that 
stress the need for prevention rather than end-of-pipe controls, which have proven to be costly 
and  frequently  ineffective.  Raising  awareness  of  the  private  sector  and  civil  society  through 
education  and  campaigns  is  an  important  part  of  government  policies.  Surveys  show  that 
awareness  among  manufacturers,  traders,  and  consumers  has  increased  from  2001  to  2008. 
However, management and implementation of food safety and hygiene is still at low levels and 
needs  to  be  stepped  up.  Involvement  of  the  private  sector  and  civil  society  in  SPS  capacity 
building  is  necessary  to  ensure  that  the  key  concerns  of  food  safety  are  properly  addressed. 
The  project  will  support  workshops  for  all  stakeholders,  including  the  private  sector,  to  raise 
awareness, provide training, and build consensus. Coordination with development partners and 
the GMS working group on agriculture will be maintained throughout. 
 
B. 
 
9. 
The intended impact of the project is that Viet Nam’s food products  will  be safer, more 
efficiently produced, and traded in greater quantities. The outcome of the project is an enhanced  
SPS and food safety management system in Viet Nam. 
 
C. 
 

Impact and Outcome 

Outputs 

1. 

Output 1: Strengthened Food Safety Surveillance, Handling, and Inspection   
Programs 

 
10.  
The  project  will  support  the  design  and  implementation  of  food  safety  surveillance, 
including (i) a  pilot in four northern provinces, (ii) import handling, (iii) grading of restaurants in 
tourist  areas,  and  (iv) strengthening  of  food  laboratories  to  support  surveillance  and  decisions 
on market access.  
 
11.  
Food  safety  surveillance.  The  project  will  focus  on  the  development  of  annual 
surveillance  programs  that  analyze  known  and  perceived  risks  to  food  safety,  in  particular 
                                                
8  ADB. 2006. Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy. Manila.  http://www.adb.org/documents/ regional-

cooperation-and-integration-strategy. 

 

 4 
 

hazards related to product types, product origins, locations, markets, major public events, hotels 
and restaurants (especially in the tourism sector), covering imported and domestic products  at 
various stages—on-farm, processing plant, and market. MOH will lead and coordinate the food 
surveillance  and  establish a food  safety  database.  Surveillance  programs  will  be  strengthened 
in the four provinces.9 
 
12. 
Improving food safety surveillance capacity in line with World Trade Organization (WTO) 
principles  will  require  mainstreaming  risk  analysis  in  national  food  safety  and  hygiene 
management, with a focus on the VFA's capacity to use risk analysis in policy preparation and 
coordination. The project will help (i) develop institutional capacity and assign mandates for risk 
assessment, risk management, and risk communication; (ii) design and implement cross-cutting 
risk  analysis  programs; (iii)  train  staff through  workshops  and  learning-by-doing; (iv) conduct  a 
food  consumption  study  and  risk  assessment  studies  for  six  food  additives;  and  (v)  increase 
standardization.  Food  safely  surveillance  will  focus  first  on  major  urban  areas,  and  core 
production  and  trading  areas  of  products  with  high  food  safety  vulnerability.  Progressively, 
annual  programs  will  cover  more  products,  parameters,  and  areas.  For  reasons  of  cost-
effectiveness, use of rapid test kits will be integrated in the sampling strategy wherever possible. 
The strengthened surveillance will make use of passive surveillance. This will be complemented 
by  active  surveillance  on  particular  products,  parameters,  and  locations.  Since  present 
operational budgets are insufficient for broader national surveillance, the project will bridge gaps 
for collecting and analyzing increased numbers of food samples. 
 
13. 
The project will also support (i) information and communication technology connections 
between the VFA, major institutes, other ministries with SPS mandates, and sub-VFAs;10 (ii) a 
database with search and statistical analysis capacity; and (iii) a server and portal. Substantial 
training will be provided for specialists in national institutions (and for users in the provinces) to 
implement  information  and  communication  technology  systems.  Test  results  from  active  and 
passive surveillance will be stored in a comprehensive database and used for (i) risk analysis; 
(ii)  management  support  and  response  to  hazards;  (iii)  an  annual  report  to  the  public;  (iv) 
reporting to other agencies involved (such as the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development 
and the  Ministry  of Industry  and  Trade  where relevant for their response);  and (v)  cooperation 
with  trading  partners,  especially  Cambodia,  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC),  the  Lao 
People’s Democratic Republic (Lao PDR), and Thailand. 
 
14.  
Import handling. The project will develop and implement advanced risk-based methods 
for  controlling  imported  processed  food  in  line  with  WTO  and  ASEAN  recommendations.  This 
will involve (i) study visits and consensus workshops; (ii) preparation of risk profiles of different 
categories  of  products  to  which  different  degrees  of  inspection  can  be  applied;  (iii) design  of 
better  inspection  manuals,  where  possible  harmonized  with  neighboring  countries,  and  their 
effective  application;  (iv)  training  support  for  implementation  of  risk-based  inspection;  and 
(v) regional  cooperation  in  handling  requests  for  first-time  market  access  approval  on  imports. 
Courses  will  be  provided  for  MOH  staff  on  principles  of  the  WTO's  SPS  agreement  and  the 
Codex Alimentarius, and the working of international and national food control systems. 
 
15. 
food  safety 
management in restaurants in tourist areas by grading them, using scorecards based on good 
hygiene practices and good manufacturing practices. This will be done through study visits and

will help (i) develop a system to upgrade food-handling safety through scorecards and grading; 
(ii) raise food safety awareness in the tourism industry; (iii) conduct training courses for private

(Khanh Hoa province) and Ha Long (Quang Ninh province). 
 
16. 
Strengthening  food  laboratories.  The  project  will  selectively  strengthen  the  national 
network  of  food  laboratories  and  government  capacity  for  national  surveillance  and  market 
access decisions. It will aim to (i) improve testing skills, (ii) bolster quality management, (iii) fill 
gaps in analytical capacity with pertinent equipment, and (iv) strengthen the National Institute for 
Food  Control  within  MOH  in  its  role  as  reference  laboratory  and  provider  of  training  to  other 
laboratories.  The  project  will  support  the  public  role  of  ensuring  that  food  is  safe  by  helping 
conduct  regular  food  tests  and  public  inspection  of  premises,  and  by  helping  prepare  the 
laboratories for  their  increasing  role.  Particular  areas that  require stronger testing  capacity  are 
(i)  pesticide  residues,  biotoxins,  hormones,  mycotoxins  and  antibiotics;  (ii) pathogens  and 
parasites  in  food;  and  (iii)  analysis  of  genetically  modified  organisms.  The  project  will  also 
improve capacity for surveillance at the provincial level.  
 

2. 

Output 2: Improved Regional Cooperation and Harmonization 

 
The  project  will  strengthen  regional  cooperation  and  harmonization  in  food  safety 
17. 
management,  in  particular  with  regard  to  surveillance  and  inspection  programs  and  import 
policies,  through  support for  bilateral  working groups  with  the  Cambodia, Lao PDR,  PRC,  and 
Thailand. The project will (i) support participation of Viet Nam officials in the working groups and 
Viet  Nam’s  active  participation  in  the  International  Food  Authorities  Network  and  the  ASEAN 
Rapid  Alert  System  for  Food  and  Feed,  and  (ii)  promote  consultation  on  import  handling.  A 
study  will  be  undertaken  on  how  Viet  Nam,  within  the  framework  of  harmonization  and 
cooperation  among  GMS  countries,  could  make  use  of  risk  assessments  by  other  GMS 
countries when responding to first-time market access requests for processed food products.11 
The project will support a study visit and training for implementing such a system in Viet Nam. 
Overarching GMS activities will also be pursued through implementation of the SPS projects for 
Lao PDR and Cambodia, and supported by the regional technical assistance.12

Technical 

 
A. 
 
23.  
The  project  has  been  designed  to  (i)  promote  complementarity  with  other  ongoing 
projects  that  support  SPS  capacity  building  in  Viet  Nam  (especially  the  Japan  International

and  Rural  Development);  (ii)  work  with  evolving  institutional  and  legal  arrangements  (e.g.,  by 
placing  lead  policy  responsibility  for  food  safety  with  the  VFA);  and  (iii)  support  current 
government  food  safety  priorities  (by  following  the  approaches  and  modalities  outlined  in  the 
National  SPS  Action  Plan).  The  WTO  principles  of  risk-based  SPS  management  are  all 
embodied  in  the  design  of  financed  activities.  Other  design  considerations  concerned  (i)  the 
need  to  deal  with  a  wider  and  more  complex  range  of  food  safety  issues  than  is  the  case  in 
smaller  neighbor  countries;  (ii)  the  need  to  systematize  and  introduce  more  rigor  into 
surveillance  planning;  (iii)  the  specific  need  to  increase  technical  capacity  in  the  provinces; 
(iv) the need to respond to evolving market access requirements of export food markets; (v) the 
need to promote risk-based food-safety practices and thereby reduce the aggregate number of 
inspections; and (vi) the need to harmonize with WTO principles and ASEAN recommendations, 
and  to adopt  international  standards in information  exchange  and reporting  on  production and 
trade in food products.  
 
24. 
The major technical design parameters are (i) a recognition that food safety surveillance 
start from a low informational and human capacity base, and that bolstering food safety capacity 
should  take  a  pragmatic  approach;  and  (ii)  promotion  of  simple  and  cost-effective  approaches 
wherever  possible (e.g.,  use  of  a combination  of  conventional  testing  and  rapid  test  kits).  The 
project  has  been  designed  to  complement  ongoing  and  planned  interventions  by  various 
development partners and ADB. Cooperation is promoted through participation in various SPS 
forums, bilateral working groups, training attachments, academic exchanges, and twinning. 
 
B. 
 
Investments  in  food  safety  capacity  building  are  justified  for  the  public  good.  In 
25. 
developing  member  countries  and  in  middle-income  contexts  such  as  Viet  Nam,  they  are 
typically part of long-term programs to establish capacity that has hitherto been largely absent.16 
Without public intervention, food safety management will be underprovided. This leads to lack of 
incentives to improve the safety and quality of food products, the persistence of relatively high 
disability-adjusted life years (DALYs), and the substantial economic costs caused by poor food 
safety.  Without  improvement,  Viet  Nam  may  become  the  destination  of  some  subgrade 
processed food products in the GMS. In this context, Viet Nam will remain a relatively weak link, 
and contribute to high reputational risk to  the GMS, especially in tourism, where many tourists 
typically visit several GMS countries in the course of an individual trip. 
 
26.  While  the  causal  relationship  between  project  outcome  and  impact  (and  thus  the 
potential  economic  benefits)  is  complex,  a  basic  estimate  of  the  benefits  arising  from  greater 
food  safety  in  Viet  Nam  could  be  made  based  on  the  Global  Burden  of  Diseases  estimates,17 
which have been used in the context of the Lao PDR.18 Using the same methodology, but with 
comparable estimates for Viet Nam, and the same income parameters, the costs to Viet Nam of 
the current poor food safety situation would be about $500 million. A 1% reduction of this loss 
would be worth $5 million a year.

D. 
 
30.    The  project  is  classified  general  intervention  and  does  not  target  poverty  directly. 
However,  by  improving  the  management  of  food  products  and  stepping  up  food  safety  in  Viet 
Nam and within the GMS, the project will help increase agricultural productivity and contribute to 
making  trade  in  food  products  more  predictable.  Improving  national  food  surveillance  reduces 
exposure to food poisoning and time off work for all, including the poor, for whom it is relatively 
more important in terms of illness costs and lost work time. In the tourism industry, the grading 
of  food-handling  establishments  will  help  stabilize  and  formalize  the  hospitality  sector,  and 
indirectly sustain relatively low-wage employment in food preparation, handling, and serving. 
 
31. 
As women’s participation in tourism-related employment (e.g., in restaurants and hotels) 
is high, they will particularly benefit from the project. The project is categorized as having some 
gender  elements.  Gender  analysis  has  been  undertaken,  including  the  composition  of  staff  in 
the  VFA  and  some  food-testing  institutes  under  MOF.  Overall,  the  gender  composition  is 
balanced,  but  women  in  management  roles  are  relatively  underrepresented.  Selected  gender 
targets  (women’s  participation  in  training)  have  been  identified  and  are  reflected  in  the  legal 
agreement and the design and monitoring framework.

32. 
The  project  is  classified  category  C  for  impacts  on  the  environment,  involuntary 
resettlement,  and  indigenous  peoples.  The  project  does  not  have  a  negative  environmental 
impact  and  there  are  no  implications  for  resettlement  of  any  persons  (as  all  system  upgrades 
will take place within existing facilities and premises).
